data.key: Acquisition of Surgical Innovation Associates, Inc.
data.value: On December 6, 2022, the Company completed its acquisition for an acquisition purchase price of $51.5 million, including contingent payments based on revenue performance milestones and FDA approval.
On January 20, 2021, the Company acquired ACell for an acquisition purchase price of $306.9 million plus up to $100 million in contingent consideration based on performance milestones.
On August 31, 2022, the Company completed the sale to Gentell for $28.8 million, including contingent consideration based on performance milestones.
On January 4, 2021, the Company sold its business to Smith & Nephew for $240.0 million.

Business combinations are accounted for in accordance with ASC Topic 805. Fair values at the date of acquisition are determined for assets acquired and liabilities assumed.
Any excess of the purchase price over the fair value of net assets acquired is recorded as goodwill.
Contingent consideration is recorded at fair value at the acquisition date, based on future financial projections.
Transaction costs and restructuring costs are expensed as incurred.
Valuations require significant judgment related to future cash flows, discount rates, and the life cycle of intangible assets.

elements.title: Leadership and Responsibilities of the Board of Directors

data.value: February 21, 2023
The Board of Directors may appoint a presiding director for a term not exceeding one year.
Determined by the Board of Directors, including presiding over meetings if the Chairman is absent.

The officers of the Corporation shall be a Chairman of the Board, a Chief Executive Officer, a President, a Chief Financial Officer, a Secretary and a Treasurer, and may include Vice Presidents, Assistant Secretaries, and Assistant Treasurers.
Officers shall be elected by the Board and hold office at its pleasure.
Any officer may be removed at any time by the Board with or without cause.
The Chairman shall preside at all meetings and perform additional duties as assigned by the Board.

Use of cash from financing activities include:
1. Purchase of treasury stock: $125.0 million
2. Cash taxes paid in net equity settlements: $24.6 million due to former CEO departure.
3. Repayments under Senior Credit Facility and Securitization Facility: $148.6 million offset by $40.8 million borrowings.

On January 12, 2022, entered into a $125 million accelerated share repurchase (2022 ASR), receiving 1.48 million shares, with an additional 0.46 million shares settled on March 24, 2022. Board authorized up to $225 million for share repurchase program, expiring December 2024.
No cash dividends have been paid since formation; future payments depend on Board discretion and financial condition.
Sufficient cash and borrowings under Senior Credit Facility to finance operations and capital expenditures for next twelve months.

elements.title: Performance Stock Vesting and Termination Conditions

data.value: The Participant shall not have any voting rights in respect of the shares of Performance Stock until such Shares shall have been issued by the Company.

(i) 33% of Target Performance Shares Vest on the first anniversary of the Award Date; (ii) 33% of Target Performance Shares Vest on the second anniversary of the Award Date; (iii) 34% of Target Performance Shares Vest on the third anniversary of the Award Date.
In case of Disability or death, shares not vested will remain outstanding and eligible to vest; otherwise, they will be forfeited.
If achieved, any Catch-Up Shares shall Vest on the third anniversary of the Award Date.

Intent to comply with Section 409A to avoid additional taxes.

elements.title: Adjustments to Restricted Stock Units and Grant Conditions

data.value: Any subdivision, consolidation, stock dividend, capital reorganization, etc. will adjust the Participant's account and RSUs to preserve their interests.
RSUs subject to clawback policies as per applicable laws, including Dodd-Frank.
If there's a conflict between the Plan and Award Agreement, the Plan governs.
The Committee interprets the Plan, adopts rules, and its actions are final and binding.
The grant of RSUs does not create future rights to grants or benefits.
The RSUs and Shares are not granted as consideration for any service the Participant may provide as a director of a Related Corporation or an Affiliate.
The RSUs and Shares are not part of normal or expected compensation with respect to severance, bonuses, pensions, or similar payments.
The future value of the Shares underlying the RSUs is unknown and cannot be predicted.
No claim for damages arises from forfeiture of RSUs resulting from employment termination.
The Company is not liable for exchange rate fluctuations affecting the value of RSUs.
The Company does not provide tax, legal, or financial advice regarding the Plan.
The Participant is responsible for all tax-related items linked to their participation in the Plan.
The Participant acknowledges tax liability in more than one jurisdiction may affect withholding requirements.
The Participant agrees to make satisfactory arrangements for tax withholding events.

The Company or Service Recipient may satisfy withholding obligations through various methods including: withholding from wages, requiring cash payment, withholding from proceeds of stock sales, or withholding in Shares.
If over-withholding occurs, the Participant may receive a refund in cash, or seek a refund from tax authorities.
The Participant may need to pay additional Tax-Related Items directly to tax authorities or the Company.
The Participant agrees to pay any required Tax-Related Items that cannot be satisfied by previous means.
The Participant has consulted their tax advisors about applicable tax consequences of their investment.

elements.title: RSUs Award Agreement Terms and Conditions

data.value: The plan is unfunded and the Company's obligations under the plan and this Award Agreement are unsecured.
RSUs shall not be considered Shares or other securities of the Company, nor do they entitle the Participant to vote or receive dividends.
Vesting of RSUs is only earned by continuing as an employee or service provider, not through being granted the award.
Notices must be addressed to the Company Secretary and to the Participant at their provided addresses.
The Company is not required to issue Shares until completion of all legal requirements.
Company shall, in its absolute discretion, deem necessary or advisable for obtaining any approval or other clearance from any U.S. or non-U.S. governmental agency.
Company shall have unilateral authority to amend this Award Agreement without the Participant’s consent.
Modifications can be made only in an express written contract executed by a duly authorized officer of the Company.
The Plan is discretionary in nature and may be amended, suspended, or terminated by the Company at any time.
Laws of the State of Delaware shall govern the interpretation and enforcement of this Award Agreement.
Parties consent to jurisdiction of the State of New Jersey for any disputes.
Rights and obligations may be assigned by the Company to a successor in the business.
Participant expressly consents to the Company’s data collection, processing, and transfer practices.

elements.title: Grant of Award and Award Agreement

data.value: If the Participant properly declines the Award, the Award will be cancelled and the Participant will not be entitled to any benefits from the Award or any compensation or benefits in lieu of the cancelled Award.

No waiver by either party of any breach of, or of compliance with, any condition or provision of this Award Agreement by the other party shall be considered a waiver of any other condition or provision or of the same condition or provision at another time.
The Notice of Grant of Award, this Award Agreement, and the Plan constitute the entire contract between the parties hereto with regard to the subject matter hereof.

The provisions of this Award Agreement are severable and if any one or more provisions are determined to be illegal or otherwise unenforceable, the remaining provisions shall nevertheless be binding and enforceable.
If the Participant has received this Award Agreement translated into a language other than English, the English version will control.

elements.title: Description of the Company’s Common Stock

data.value: The Company’s authorized capital stock consists of 255,000,000 shares of stock, of which 240,000,000 shares are designated as common stock, par value $0.01 per share, and 15,000,000 shares are designated as preferred stock, no par value.
As of December 31, 2022, we had 90,476,671 shares of common stock outstanding, 6,822,864 shares were designated as treasury stock, and no shares of preferred stock outstanding.

Holders of outstanding shares of common stock are entitled to receive dividends out of assets legally available, subject to preferences that may apply to shares of preferred stock outstanding. The ability to pay dividends is limited by the Company’s senior credit facility.

Any future determinations to pay cash dividends on our common stock will be at the discretion of the board of directors and depend on financial condition, results of operations, cash flows and other factors.
Each stockholder is entitled to one vote for each share held, without cumulative voting rights. Directors are elected annually.
Upon liquidation, holders of common stock would share ratably in distributions after all liabilities and preferred stock preferences are satisfied.
The common stock is traded on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol 'IART'.

elements.title: Risk Factors Regarding Supply Chain and Regulation

data.value: Certain components and raw materials are available only from a sole supplier.
Subject to extensive regulation by the FDA and other federal and state authorities.
Deep flexor tendon and fetal bovine skin are in the lowest-risk category for BSE transmission.
We rely upon trade secrets and technological innovations along with patent and trademark protection.
Fourth quarter revenues tend to be stronger due to hospital purchasing cycles.

elements.title: Risk Factors - Compliance with Data Privacy and Cybersecurity Laws

data.value: We are subject to requirements relating to information technology which could adversely affect our business.
Complications in business practices, operations, and management requirements.
May complicate clinical research activities and product offerings involving clinical data.
70% in the United States, 21% in Europe, 2% in Latin America and Canada, 7% in Asia Pacific.
Executive leadership sets diversity and inclusion goals annually.
Established in 2017, chaired by Jan De Witte.
Concerns regarding future financial performance, including financing plans and competition impact.
Anticipated demand for products, particularly capital equipment.
Ability to produce and deliver products to meet sales demands.
Failure to comply with regulations related to quality standards could adversely affect financial condition.
Ability to obtain additional debt and equity financing for capital expenditures and working capital.
Physicians' willingness to adopt products and third-party payors' reimbursement.
Ability to protect intellectual property and trade secrets.
Ability to complete acquisitions and maintain customer relationships post-acquisition.
Ability to remediate matters identified in FDA observations.
Impact of global economic conditions on operations.
Impact of COVID-19 on global supply chain and costs.
Potential decreased demand due to economic uncertainty.

elements.title: Impact of COVID-19 on Operations and Supply Chain Risks

data.value: Exposure to risks associated with public health crises, including epidemics and pandemics such as COVID-19, causing significant volatility and uncertainty in global economies.
Disruptions in the global supply chain primarily through a lack of availability of raw materials and components, leading to longer shipping times and increased costs.
Challenges associated with material and component availability, logistics capacity, skilled labor availability, and increased costs across various sectors.
Uneven recovery pace due to direct and indirect disruptions caused by the pandemic and responses from governments and individuals.
Potential fluctuations in operating results that could affect stock price due to various economic factors and disruptions.

Economic conditions, impact of acquisitions, integration challenges, competition, timing of customer orders, changes in market acceptance, retention of employees, regulatory approvals, exchange rates, and operational disruptions due to natural events.

elements.title: Risks related to acquisitions and product market acceptance

data.value: Potential inability to identify suitable acquisition candidates, obtain financing or consummate acquisitions. Antitrust laws impacting acquisition strategy.
Failure in acquisition strategy could adversely impact financial performance.
Unanticipated costs in business integration could affect earnings.
Annual testing of goodwill and intangible assets for impairment, risks associated with market changes.
Dependence on market acceptance of products and competition with established technologies.
Unfavorable reimbursement decisions may impact product acceptance.
Continuous changes in healthcare due to consolidation, technological improvements, and reform.
High costs and competition in developing and commercializing new products.

elements.title: Risks Related to Tax and Debt Obligations

data.value: Changes in tax laws or exposures to additional tax liabilities could negatively impact the Company's operating results.
Our leverage and debt service obligations could adversely affect our business, making it more difficult to satisfy financial obligations.
Changes in the calculation and complete replacement of LIBOR could impact our business, with potential higher interest costs.
Our intellectual property rights may not provide meaningful commercial protection, enabling third parties to use our technology.

elements.title: Risks Related to Intellectual Property and Global Operations

data.value: Our success will depend partly on our ability to operate without infringing or misappropriating the proprietary rights of others.
We may be involved in lawsuits relating to our intellectual property rights and promotional practices, which may be expensive.
If any of our facilities or those of our suppliers were damaged, we could experience lost revenues and our business could be seriously harmed.
Our insurance might not cover all losses and we may not be able to renew or obtain such insurance on acceptable terms.
Climate change may increase the frequency and severity of extreme weather conditions and natural disasters.

elements.title: Currency Exchange Risk and Regulatory Challenges

data.value: Currency exchange risk due to operations in multiple foreign currencies, significant risks with currencies like AUD, GBP, CAD, CNY, EUR, JPY, and CHF.
Subject to laws regarding transactions in sanctioned countries, customs, U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, and product registration requirements.
Russia-Ukraine conflict creating barriers and impacting global supply chains, monitoring impacts of sanctions.
Brexit causing uncertainty in regulatory environments, potential restrictions on imports/exports, and currency volatility.
U.S. government changes to trade policies impacting tariffs and trade agreements with countries like China.
Cyber-attacks disrupting information technology systems could adversely affect business.

elements.title: Performance Vesting Percentage and Award of Performance Stock

data.value: Percentage determined based on achievement of Performance Goals during the Performance Period.
Termination of Service by the Company without Cause or by the Participant for Good Reason.
When the Participant ceases to provide services to the Company and its Related Corporations.
Condition that shares of Performance Stock must meet to be considered vested.
Amounts equal to the regular quarterly cash dividend paid to Vested but unissued shares of Performance Stock.

elements.title: CHINA Terms and Conditions of Participation in the Plan

data.value: The Participant acknowledges that the participation is subject to Company obtaining approval from the State Administration of Foreign Exchange.
The Participant agrees that the Company can sell Shares on the Participant’s behalf to comply with laws and regulations.
Shares must be sold within sixty days following termination of employment.
Shares must be held in a designated broker account and sold through that broker.
The Participant understands that cash dividends paid on Shares may be transferred to a special exchange control account required by the Company.
The Participant agrees to bear any currency fluctuation risk between the time the Shares are sold or dividends are paid and the time the proceeds are distributed.
French residents must declare any cash or securities held outside France and face penalties for non-compliance.
The Participant must report cross-border payments over €12,500 to the German Federal Bank.
Participants must report acquisitions leading to a qualified participation if they exceed €150,000.

elements.title: FDA Regulations and Compliance for Medical Devices and HCT/Ps

data.value: Products are regulated by the FDA for safety, efficacy, and quality standards.
Consequences of non-compliance include fines, penalties, and product recalls.
The approval process for medical devices can take several years and may involve clinical trials.
Human Cells, Tissues, and Cellular and Tissue-Based Products regulated under specific FDA guidelines.
Accreditation by the American Association of Tissue Banks is necessary for tissue establishments.
Guidance on minimal manipulation and homologous use was issued by the FDA in July 2020.

elements.title: FDA Guidance on Medical Devices and Enforcement Actions

data.value: The FDA maintains that certain products do not meet criteria for regulation solely as HCT/Ps.
Extended to May 31, 2021, some uses could be subject to immediate enforcement.
The Company discontinued manufacturing certain products before the enforcement deadline.
No further enforcement notice received from the FDA as of December 31, 2022.
Required for introducing new medical devices or new indications for existing devices.
Reserved for new devices not substantially equivalent to any predicate device.
Manufacturers must register with the FDA and comply with extensive regulations.
FDA's requirements for maintaining documents in prescribed manner.
Integra manufacturing facilities audited annually under Medical Device Single Audit Program.
Devices must comply with GSPR under EU Medical Devices Regulation.
Required for marketing in the EEA, transition to new EU MDR requirements might pose challenges for continuing to market products in the EU.
Subject to stringent domestic and foreign medical device regulations.
Includes FDA Quality System Regulations, reporting for adverse events, and recalls.
Subject to U.S. and foreign laws related to healthcare fraud and marketing practices.
Laws regarding sanctioned countries and restrictions affecting operations.
Compliance with environmental and safety laws for hazardous materials used in processes.
Integra may face a regulatory shutdown of a facility impacting product distribution.
Potential substantial costs to comply with future environmental laws.
Compliance procedures are essential for business objectives.
Healthcare providers rely on third-party payors for product cost coverage.
Compliance with data privacy laws may lead to increased costs and regulatory enforcement.
Obligated to comply with HIPAA for protecting patient health information.
Subject to EU GDPR for processing personal data of EU residents.

elements.title: Risks Related to Our Regulatory Environment

data.value: Economic and political instability could adversely affect hospitals' ability to access funds impacting budgets and production.
Health care reforms and government initiatives may adversely impact business and financial outcomes.
Recent legislation has reduced Medicare and Medicaid payments impacting healthcare providers.
FDA policies may change affecting product approval and compliance.
Market stress from regulatory changes may affect customer purchasing decisions.
Potential future healthcare reforms could change reimbursement dynamics, impacting product demand.
Various agencies monitor and enforce compliance with laws and regulations governing medical devices.
Obtaining marketing approval from FDA and foreign regulatory agencies is costly and can lead to delays.
Failure to comply with regulations can result in significant enforcement actions, including halting studies and penalties.
Expenditures for compliance amounted to $45.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022.
The regulatory environment in China is evolving and may impact operations and lead to fines.
Healthcare companies must comply with regulations like the Anti-Kickback Statute and False Claims Act.
Adopted the AdvaMed Code of Ethics for best practices in interactions with healthcare providers.
Subject to EU regulations regarding personal data.
Subject to state laws on privacy in the U.S.
Focus on protecting personal information and requires compliance.
Fines up to 4% of global annual revenue possible.
Medical device products subject to additional reporting even post-approval.
Subject to special scrutiny and regulations due to animal origin.
Products derived from animal tissues could face additional regulations.
FDA powers in enforcing recalls on defective products.
Delays and failures in compliance may lead to reputational harm and financial losses.
Received approval in the U.S., the EU, Japan, Taiwan, China, Argentina.
Potential prohibition on collagen product sales if sourcing from BSE-free countries is disrupted.
Subject to environmental laws, which may impose compliance costs.
Controlled use of hazardous materials in manufacturing and R&D.
Potential liability from accidents or contamination related to hazardous materials.
Subject to physical and transition risks related to climate change.
Subject to data privacy and cybersecurity laws across jurisdictions.
Increasing challenges in recruiting and retaining skilled employees.
Subject to income taxes and audits, with uncertainties in tax determination.

elements.title: INTEGRA LIFESCIENCES HOLDINGS CORPORATION NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

data.value: The Company entered into cross-currency swap agreements to convert a notional amount of $471.6 million equivalent to 420.1 million of a CHF-denominated intercompany loan into U.S. dollars.
The total fair value liability across all swaps ranges from $(7,769) to $(8,242).
The Company manages certain foreign exchange risks through a variety of strategies, including hedging.
The Company settled cross-currency swaps designated as cash flow hedges of an intercompany loan with aggregate notional amounts of $100 million.
Based on the closing exchange rates, the gain upon settlement of these swaps was approximately $1.6 million.
February 21, 2023
Any person who was or is a party to any action, suit or proceeding shall be indemnified by the Corporation against expenses, judgments, fines, excise taxes, and amounts paid in settlement.
Expenses incurred in defending any action shall be paid by the Corporation in advance of the final disposition.
Indemnification or advances shall be made within sixty (60) days upon written request.
The burden of proving the defense rests on the Corporation.
February 21, 2023
Delaware Courts or U.S. Federal District Courts
Derivative actions, breach of fiduciary duty claims, claims against the Corporation or officers/employees
Remaining provisions remain effective; intent given effect despite invalidity.

elements.title: Anti-Takeover Effects and Business Combination Provision

data.value: The Board of Directors has authority to issue up to 15,000,000 shares of Preferred Stock.
Issuing preferred stock could decrease the market price of common stock.
Prevents 15%+ stockholders from business combinations for three years unless certain conditions are met.
Business combinations require approval from the Board and/or a supermajority of non-interested stockholders.
Provisions in bylaws may discourage tender offers and takeover attempts.
May only be called by the chairman, president, or Board.
Stockholders can act by written consent with Board's record date setting.
Filled exclusively by the remaining Board members.
Directors can only be removed for cause by a vote of 80% of outstanding stock.

elements.title: Data Protection Laws and Participant Rights

data.value: The Company will use the Participant’s personal data only as long as necessary, generally seven years after participation, ceasing when no longer needed.

The Participant may have rights under data privacy laws including access to data, rectification, deletion, restrictions on processing, objection to processing, portability, lodging complaints, and receiving a list of data recipients.
Providing personal data is necessary for contractual obligations related to the Award Agreement.
The Plan applies to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 and complies with the Corporations Act 2001 in Australia.
The company's reliance on outside vendors, some of whom are sole-source suppliers, for crucial components and raw materials.
Interruption in supply could harm manufacturing ability until a new or alternative source is identified.
Collagen-based and bovine-based products, silicone products, specialty parts, biosynthetic products, amniotic and porcine tissue-based products.
Dependence on third-party suppliers for sterilization and potential disruptions from those suppliers.
Unanticipated price increases due to economic disruptions, component shortages, inflation, recessionary conditions, and geopolitical events.
Policy is to maintain sufficient inventory to mitigate disruptions.
Consolidation of facilities could present challenges such as unexpected costs and operational impacts.
Risk of product liability claims and insurance coverage limitations.
The research and development activities focus on identifying unmet surgical needs and addressing those with innovative solutions and products.
Apply core competency in regenerative technology to innovate products for neurosurgical, wound applications, plastic surgery, and reconstructive surgery.
A large portion of the research and development budget is allocated to projects involving regenerative technology.
Conduct extensive R&D development programs targeting the core platforms of electromechanical technologies.
Conduct products and clinical studies to generate efficacy and health economic evidence.
Integra is a world leader in regenerative technology and was the first to receive FDA claim for regeneration of dermal tissue.

elements.title: Diversity and Inclusion Initiatives at Integra

data.value: The Council focuses on attracting and retaining female talent, advancing women into leadership roles, increasing cultural awareness of inclusion and diversity, and creating development forums for high-performing women.
Members of the Executive Leadership Team serve as sponsors for Integra’s employee resource groups.

Currently, Integra has six Employee Resources Groups including Women of Integra Networks (WIN), African American Affinity Group, Veteran Employee Resource Group, Indian American Network, Asian American and Pacific Islander Network, and Integra PRIDE.
Integra partners with organizations such as CEO Action for Diversity & Inclusion and Healthcare Businesswomen’s Association.
Programs include Managing Unconscious Bias and Practicing Inclusion, which are mandatory for all new hires.
48% of the overall population is female, 38% of executive leaders and 43% of senior leaders are female.
The document discusses risks associated with cybersecurity threats affecting business operations and the implementation of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Corporate Governance) practices.
Increased risks due to internet reliance and remote work during COVID-19, potential for data breaches and unauthorized access.
Focus on climate change, sustainability, and corporate governance, including a published inaugural ESG report.
Potential negative impacts on reputation, financial condition, and customer or investor relations if ESG practices fail to meet expectations.
No unresolved comments from the SEC as of the filing date.
Leased office space in Princeton, NJ, with a lease expiring in 2035.

elements.title: FDA Matters regarding product launches and regulatory actions

data.value: Launched in 2022 for peripheral nerve repair.
Completed trials for DFU management, enrolled over 225 patients.
Announced positive clinical data on 2020 for complex lower extremity reconstruction.
Global product removal initiated on August 18, 2022 due to out-of-range pressure readings.
Received from FDA on March 6, 2019 regarding quality systems issues.
Issued post-inspection with observations requiring corrective actions.
$1.9 million provision for product returns and $0.8 million rework accrual in 2022.
